abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Greater Mekong Subregion
            Power Trade Project for Cambodia were as follows: outcomes
            not applicable; risk to development outcome was also not
            applicable; Bank performance was moderately unsatisfactory;
            and borrower performance was also moderately unsatisfactory.
            A two-year closing date extension was included in the Royal
            Government of Cambodia's (RGC's) official
            restructuring request in August 2010. Initially, the Bank
            informed RGC that it would confirm the project restructuring
            only if the implementing agency could demonstrate concrete
            progress in preparing the new 230 kV transmission line
            (notably processing the necessary procurement that would
            ensure project completion by December 31, 2013). In June
            2011, Bank management informed Electricite du Cambodge (EDC)
            that the RGC's request for project
            restructuring-including the closing date extension and a
            change in the project development objective to remove
            reference to Vietnam-could not be processed due to country
            program conditions. Without the two year extension of the
            closing date, EDC could not proceed with International
            Competitive Bidding (ICB) procurement for the supply and
            installation of the 230 kV line because it could not afford
            to self-finance the associated works. EDC would also suffer
            huge financial losses if it did finance the line and then
            Lao PDR was unable to meet the agreed schedule. Seeing no
            viable options, RGC requested a full cancellation of the
            grant for this project on October 4, 2011.
